TextView.android:text: What is Income Tax?
Lesson 1
Tax is imposed annually on individuals who receive income in respect of:
a) Gains / profit from a business;
b) Gains / profit from employment;
c) Dividends, interest or discounts;
d) Rent, royalties or premiums;
e) Pensions, annuities or other periodic payments; and
f) Gains / profit not falling under any of the foregoing paragraphs.
The Income Tax Act 1967 (ITA) enforces administration and collection of income tax on persons and taxable income.
The Inland Revenue Board of Malaysia (IRBM) is one of the main revenue collecting agencies of the Ministry of Finance.
Who is taxable?
Lesson 2
Income tax in Malaysia is imposed on the income of any person that is accrued, derived or received in Malaysia.
If an individual's total taxable income exceeds the threshold value, they are required to register for an income tax file.
The tax liability and applicable tax reliefs for an individual depend on their residency status.
Resident individuals are taxed based on the tax rate and eligible for tax reliefs as per Section 45A-49 of the ITA 1967.
On the other hand, non-resident individuals are subject to a flat tax rate of 30% and cannot enjoy any reliefs.
Any income sourced from outside Malaysia and received in Malaysia is exempted from taxation.
To summarize, Malaysian income tax applies to income earned in Malaysia or received from outside Malaysia, and the tax liability and reliefs are based on the individual's residency status.
When is Taxable
Lesson 3
In Malaysia, income is considered taxable if it meets certain criteria.
Specifically, income is taxable if it is accrued, derived, or received within Malaysia, or if it is received in Malaysia from outside the country.
The Malaysian tax system operates on a territorial principle, meaning that income is taxed based on its source rather than the residence or nationality of the individual.
This means that even if an individual is not a resident of Malaysia, any income they earn within the country is still subject to Malaysian income tax.
Similarly, if an individual receives income from outside Malaysia but it is received in Malaysia, it is also subject to Malaysian income tax.
Taxable income can include a range of sources, such as employment income, business profits, rental income, and investment income.
The amount of tax an individual pays depends on their income level, with higher income earners typically paying a higher rate of tax.
To ensure compliance with the tax laws, individuals are required to register for an income tax file and file an annual tax return.
The Malaysian tax authorities also have the power to investigate cases of suspected tax evasion or non-compliance. Failure to comply with the tax laws can result in penalties and fines.
How to file your tax?
Lesson 4
To file your tax in Malaysia, you first need to register for an income tax file number.
You can do this by completing and submitting Form CP1 to the Inland Revenue Board of Malaysia (IRBM).;
Once you have registered, you will receive a notification letter containing your tax file number and other relevant details.
As a taxpayer, you are required to file your tax return annually, with the deadline typically falling on April 30th of the following year.
To file your tax return, you can either do so online through the IRBM's e-filing system or by submitting a physical tax return form (Form BE) to the nearest IRBM branch.
If you choose to e-file, you will need to first register for an e-filing account on the IRBM website and follow the instructions provided.
When filing your tax return, you will need to provide details of your income and tax reliefs, as well as any deductions or exemptions you are eligible for.
After submitting your tax return, you will receive a tax assessment notice from the IRBM, which will indicate the amount of tax you are required to pay (if any) or any refund due.
If you disagree with the assessment, you can lodge an appeal with the IRBM within 30 days of the date of the notice.
Why we must pay tax?
Lesson 5
The primary reason for paying tax in Malaysia is to contribute to the country's development and progress.
Tax revenue is used by the government to fund public services and infrastructure, such as healthcare, education, transportation, and public utilities.
It is also used to support social welfare programs and provide assistance to those in need.
Another reason for paying tax is to promote social and economic equality by redistributing wealth from higher income earners to those in lower income brackets.
The Malaysian tax system is progressive, meaning that higher income earners are subject to a higher tax rate, while those in lower income brackets may be eligible for tax reliefs and exemptions.;
By paying tax, individuals also fulfill their civic duty and contribute to the country's overall welfare and development.
Failure to pay tax can result in penalties and legal action, as well as damage to an individual's reputation and credibility.
Additionally, tax compliance is required for certain transactions and activities, such as obtaining a business license or applying for a loan.
Overall, paying tax is a crucial aspect of being a responsible and active member of Malaysian society, helping to support the common good and promote the welfare of all citizens.
How to submit your ITRF
Lesson 6
To submit your Income Tax Return Form (ITRF) in Malaysia, gather all necessary documents and information, including Form EA, Form EC, and supporting documents related to income and expenses.
Complete the ITRF form manually or electronically via the e-Filing system on the Inland Revenue Board of Malaysia (IRBM) website.
Double-check the form for accuracy and completeness before submitting.
Submit the ITRF form electronically through the e-Filing system or manually at any IRBM branch.
If submitting manually, include all necessary supporting documents, such as EA Form and receipts.
Contact the IRBM through their hotline, email or website for assistance or questions.
The deadline for submitting your ITRF in Malaysia is typically April 30th each year, but it may vary.
Check the IRBM website or consult with a tax professional to confirm the deadline.
Failing to submit the ITRF on time may result in penalties and fines.
